title: Breaking down who the 49ers will play in the Divisional Round of the 2026 NFL Playoffs
description: The 49ers held on late to beat the Eagles in the Wild Card Round. We break down who they will play in the Divisional Round of the 2026 NFL Playoffs
fullText:
The San Francisco 49ers overcame numerous injuries to stun the Philadelphia Eagles 23-19 in the Wild Card Round. The 49ers lost tight end George Kittle and starting safety Ji‚ÄôAyir Brown but still managed to take care of business on both sides of the ball. It wasn‚Äôt pretty, but the 49ers are headed to the Divisional Round. The Eagles took a lead into the fourth quarter when the 49ers took their first lead on a trick play touchdown pass from Jauan Jennings to Christian McCaffrey. The teams exchanged touchdowns after that, and the 49ers were able to stop the Eagles in the final minute.

The 49ers will not travel to the Emerald City for a rubber match against the Seahawks. The NFL re-seeds after the Wild Card Round and the 49ers are the worst remaining seed. That also means the Rams will travel to face the Bears next weekend. The Seahawks are the No. 1 seed and had a first round bye.

Record: 23-31 regular season, 1-1 postseason

The 49ers and Seahawks have split the season series the past two years. The road team won both games this season, with Seattle securing the No. 1 seed with a 13-3 win in Week 18. The last time they met in the playoffs was 2023, when the 49ers won their Wild Card Round matchup 41-23.

Spread: Seahawks -7
Total: 46.5
Moneyline: Seahawks -330, 49ers +265

The 49ers did not reach the playoffs last year, but advanced past the Divisional Round each of the previous three seasons, and four of the past five. They had two Super Bowl losses and two NFC Championship losses in those games. This is the 27th time they have played in the Divisional Round.

title: 2026 NFL Draft order: Updated first-round picks after Raiders secure No. 1 pick
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars clinched the 24th pick in the 2026 NFL draft with their wild card loss to the Bills ‚Äî but that pick has been traded to Cleveland, so the Browns now have Pick No. 24, as well as their own Pick No. 6.
fullText:
The Jacksonville Jaguars clinched the 24th pick in the 2026 NFL draft with their wild card loss to the Bills ‚Äî but that pick has been traded to Cleveland, so the Browns now have Pick No. 24, as well as their own Pick No. 6. Here's how the draft order looks after the start of the playoffs:

13. Falcons (traded first-round pick to Rams)

16. Colts (traded first-round pick to Jets)

20. Packers (traded first-round pick to Cowboys)

24. Jaguars (traded first-round pick to Browns)

The Las Vegas Raiders earned the first overall pick by having with the easiest schedule of the four teams that finished tied with the worst record in the NFL, 3-14.

Draft picks are awarded in order of lowest winning percentage, and the tiebreaker is opponents‚Äô winning percentage, with the team that played the easiest schedule picking first. If two teams have the same record and same strength of schedule, division or conference tiebreakers are applied. If the divisional or conference tiebreakers are not applicable, or ties still exist between teams of different conferences, ties will be broken the following tie-breaking method:

Best won-lost-tied percentage in common games (minimum of four)

Strength of victory in all games

Best combined ranking among all teams in points scored and points allowed in all games

Best net touchdowns in all games

The 18 non-playoff teams get the first 18 picks. The six wild card round playoff losers get picks 19-24, the four divisional round losers get picks 25-28, the conference championship game losers get picks 29 and 30, the Super Bowl loser gets pick 31 and the Super Bowl winner gets pick 32.

The 2026 NFL draft takes place April 23-25 in Pittsburgh. The first round will be on Thursday night, the second and third rounds will be on Friday night, and the fourth through seventh rounds will be on Saturday.

Indiana quarterback Fernando Mendoza is the betting favorite to go first overall. Other contenders include Oregon quarterback Dante Moore, Miami defensive end Rueben Bain, Ohio State linebacker Arvell Reese, Ole Miss quarterback Trinidad Chambliss and Auburn defensive end Keldric Faulk

title: 2026 NFL offseason preview: Philadelphia Eagles' Super Bowl window hinges on fixing a broken offense
description: Here's a look at the offseason work ahead for the Philadelphia Eagles.
fullText:
The NFL offseason has begun, and Yahoo Sports is previewing the coming months for all 32 teams, from free agency through the draft and more.

AFC East: Bills | Dolphins | Patriots | Jets
AFC North: Ravens | Bengals | Browns | Steelers 
AFC South: Texans | Colts | Jaguars | Titans 
AFC West: Broncos | Chiefs | Raiders | Chargers 
NFC East: Cowboys | Giants | Eagles | Commanders 
NFC North: Bears | Lions | Packers | Vikings 
NFC South: Falcons | Panthers | Saints | Buccaneers 
NFC West: Cardinals | Rams | 49ers | Seahawks

2025 season record: 11-6 (u 11.5 wins), first in NFC East, lost to 49ers in wild-card round, 13th in DVOA

This was not the world-beating team so many expected to see after last year‚Äôs Super Bowl title. Last season. Philadelphia battled with some inconsistency in the offense but found a groove by the end of the season. The 2025 version never fully got it.

How the Eagles played in games was telling. In 2024, they were 24th in points per drive on their opening possession, but improved to fifth over the rest of the game. The 2025 Eagles were sixth in points per drive on their opening possession, but dropped to 25th on all following drives. The 2024 Eagles figured it out, while the 2025 version couldn‚Äôt adapt. Offensive coordinator Kevin Patullo might take the fall for that, failing to replicate the work Kellen Moore did previously.

The talent is still overwhelming. That was the case with a defense that was still second in EPA per play while developing multiple All-Pro-caliber players. But, also as the defense proved, this team needs to figure out how to make that talent work together instead of just relying on the talent to carry itself.

The Eagles have just over $14 million in effective cap space, per Over The Cap. That ranks 16th. They‚Äôre fairly locked into this roster. Because of how the Eagles have structured their contracts, there‚Äôs not a lot of restructure potential ‚Äî most contracts are pre-restuctured with small base salaries and option bonuses. If the Eagles re-sign Dallas Goedert early, they could create space by shrinking the $20.5 million figure that would hit the cap when his contract voids on Feb. 16.

TE Dallas Goedert 
Edge Jaelan Phillips 
LB Nakobe Dean 
S Reed Blankenship

Goedert led the team and was ninth in the league with a 27.8% target share in the red zone. His 10 red zone touchdowns were second only to Davante Adams. Jaelan Phillips was a defense-changer after the trade that brought him to Philadelphia. From Weeks 1-9, the Eagles were 14th in pressure rate. After Phillips was acquired, they ranked fifth. Dean has been excellent and was immediately put back into the starting lineup when he returned from injury, but the presence of Jihaad Campbell and the high rate of nickel defense will likely make Dean expendable in free agency.

Quinyon Mitchell and Cooper DeJean are two of the best players at their positions, but the second outside cornerback spot was a hole all season. Adoree‚Äô Jackson was one of the most targeted cornerbacks on a per-snap basis and the Eagles ranked 24th in DVOA against WR2s.

Even if Goedert is re-signed, the Eagles should add a tight end to the mix. Grant Calcaterra was a negative as a blocker and did not make up for it enough as a receiver ‚Äî though the Eagles were fifth in EPA per play from 12 personnel, which they ran at the 12th-highest rate in the league.

Depth on the edge will need to be addressed. That was the reason for the Phillips trade and bringing Brandon Graham out of retirement. Neither of them is under contract for 2026.

The Eagles have built their dominance through the trenches, and now they find Lane Johnson‚Äôs long-term replacement. Lomu moves well for his size, and has polished technique and can add even more weight and strength. He can learn behind Jeff Stoutland and the All-Pros they have along the line before taking over himself.

The Eagles went 10-7 against the spread in the 2025-26 regular season, but were only 8-7 ATS as a favorite. They were also a surprisingly poor 4-4 ATS at home. ‚Äî Ben Fawkes

title: Breaking down who the Bears will play in the Divisional Round of the 2026 NFL Playoffs
description: The Bears came back from a 21-3 deficit to stun the Packers. We break down who they will play in the Divisional Round of the 2026 NFL Playoffs
fullText:
The Chicago Bears came back for a wild 31-27 win over the Green Bay Packers in Saturday‚Äôs Wild Card matchup. The Packers jumped out to a 21-3 lead and looked like they would cruise to victory. But as we‚Äôve seen this season, the Bears win the un-winnable games. They fought back with a 25-point fourth quarter and won it in the closing seconds.

Sunday result: The 49ers beat the Eagles to close out the NFC‚Äôs Wild Card Round. The win means the Bears will host the Rams in the Divisional Round.

The Bears will host either the Eagles or the Rams in the Divisional Round. If the Eagles beat the 49ers, Chicago would host Philly next weekend. If the 49ers upset the Eagles, Chicago would host LA in the Divisional Round.

Record: 54-38-3 regular season, 1-1 postseason all-time

The Bears beat the Rams 24-18 at Soldier Field a year ago. The two teams haven‚Äôt met in the playoffs since 1986, when the Bears beat the Rams 24-0 in the NFC Championship en route to their Super Bowl victory over the Patriots.

Spread: Rams -4.5
Total: 50.5
Moneyline: Rams -190, Bears +160

The Bears return to the Divisional Round for the first time since 2011. They were the No. 2 seed that season and had a first round bye. They beat the Seahawks in that round and then lost to the Packers in the NFC Championship. This marks their 13th appearance in the Divisional Round.

title: Breaking down who the TEAMNAME will play in the Divisional Round of the 2026 NFL Playoffs
description: The Rams won a wild one over the Panthers in the Wild Card Round. We break down who they will play in the Divisional Round of the 2026 NFL Playoffs
fullText:
The 2026 NFL Playoffs are underway and we got a fantastic first matchup of the Wild Card Round. The Los Angeles Rams beat the Carolina Panthers 34-31 to advance to the Divisional Round. LA jumped out to 14-0 lead but Carolina fought back and took this game down to the wire. Matthew Stafford found Colby Parkinson for a game-winning touchdown with 38 seconds left to help LA advance.

Sunday result: The 49ers beat the Eagles in the final NFC Wild Card game. That means the Rams will travel to face the Bears in the Divisional Round.

Saturday Packers-Bears result: The Bears beat the Packers on Saturday 31-27 after mounting a massive comeback. Chicago trailed 21-3 in the second quarter, but put up 25 points in the fourth quarter to complete the wild comeback. The Bears win means the Rams won‚Äôt know their Divisional Round opponent until Sunday evening. If the Eagles beat the 49ers, LA will travel to face Seattle. If the 49ers upset the Eagles, LA will travel to face Chicago.

The Rams will find out their opponent either Saturday night or early Sunday evening. The NFL re-seeds the playoff bracket for the Divisional Round, which means the top-seeded Seahawks face the worst remaining seed, and the two middle seeds face off. If the Bears beat the Packers on Saturday night, the Rams will face one of the Bears, Eagles, or Seahawks in the Divisional Round. That will depend on the outcome of 49ers-Eagles on Sunday. opponent until after the 49ers and Eagles play on Sunday. However, if the Packers upset the Bears, then the Rams know they‚Äôll face the winner of 49ers-Eagles next week.

Record: 38-54-3 regular season, 1-1 postseason all-time

The Rams played the Bears a year ago, losing in Chicago 24-18. They haven‚Äôt met in the playoffs since 1986 when the Bears won 24-0 in the NFC Championship en route to their lone Super Bowl victory.

Spread: Rams -4.5
Total: 50.5
Moneyline: Rams -190, Bears +160

This marks the second straight season the Rams have reached the Divisional Round. Last year they advanced before losing to the Eagles. The last time they won in the Divisional Round came in 2022, when they beat the Buccaneers en route to winning the Super Bowl. This will be LA‚Äôs 21st appearance in the Divisional Round.

title: Breaking down who the Seahawks will play in the Divisional Round of the 2026 NFL Playoffs
description: The Seahawks have the NFC‚Äôs No. 1 seed in the 2026 NFL Playoffs. We break down who they could play in the Divisional Round.
fullText:
The Seattle Seahawks are headed back to the playoffs for the first time since 2022, and they‚Äôre going in as the betting favorite to run the table and win Super Bowl 60. They beat the San Francisco 49ers on Saturday of Week 18 to clinch the NFC West title and the No. 1 seed in the NFC playoff bracket.

The No. 1 seed comes with a first round bye, which will give Seattle time to rest and get some players back from the injury list. In their finale against the 49ers, they played without left tackle Charles Cross and free safety Coby Bryant. They got the win and it netted an extra week for Cross and Bryant to get healthy.

Sunday result: The 49ers upset the Eagles in Philadelphia to close out the NFC Wild Card Round. The Seahawks will host the 49ers in the Divisional Round.

Saturday Packers-Bears result: The Bears advanced to the Divisional Round with a huge comeback win over the Packers. Green Bay jumped out to a 21-3 lead, but managed to blow it in the fourth quarter. Chicago scored 25 points in the fourth quarter en route to a 31-27 victory. The win means we‚Äôll have to wait until Sunday to finalize the NFC Divisional Round bracket. If the Eagles beat the 49ers, Seattle will host LA and Chicago will host Philly. If the 49ers upset the Eagles, Seattle would host San Francisco and Chicago would host LA.

Saturday Rams-Panthers update: The Rams won a wild one over the Panthers to open the 2026 NFL Playoffs. It does not tell us much more about the Seahawks Divisional Round opponent other than to eliminate the Panthers from the list.

The NFL re-seeds its bracket after the Wild Card round. That means the Seahawks will face the worst remaining seed rather than knowing it will be one of two teams. If all the higher seeds win in the Wild Card round, Seattle would play the No. 4 seeded Carolina Panthers. If all the lower seeds create upsets, Seattle would play the No. 7 seeded Green Bay Packers. It could fall anywhere in between depending on how the higher seeds perform, with the San Francisco 49ers and Los Angeles Rams also in the mix as potential opponents. The Seahawks could know their Divisional Round opponent as soon as Saturday night if the Packers upset the Bears. Otherwise, they‚Äôll find out their opponent by the close of the 49ers-Eagles game on Sunday.

Record: 31-23 regular season, 1-1 postseason all-time

The teams split their regular season series, with each team winning the road game. The Seahawks won the Week 18 finale to clinch the NFC West and the No. 1 seed. The last time they faced off in the playoffs was 2023, with the 49ers winning 41-23.

49ers @ Seahawks
Spread: Seahawks -7
Total: 46.5
Moneyline: Seahawks -330, 49ers +265

The Seahawks return to the playoffs after a two-season absence. They lost in the Wild Card round in 2022, and lost in the same round two seasons prior. The last time they played in the Divisional Round was 2019, where they won a wild card game and then lost to the Packers.

This marks the fourth time the Seahawks have earned the No. 1 seed. The previous instances were in 2005, 2013, and 2014. They reached the Super Bowl in all three of those seasons, and won it in 2013.

title: Bills win nail-biter at Jags to keep Allen's Super Bowl hopes alive
description: The NFL play-offs continue with another nail-biting game as Josh Allen's Buffalo Bills claim a 27-24 win at the Jacksonville Jaguars.
fullText:
The NFL play-offs continued with another nail-biting game as the Buffalo Bills claimed a 27-24 win at the Jacksonville Jaguars.

A late interception by Buffalo safety Cole Bishop allowed the Bills to clinch victory after Josh Allen, the league's reigning Most Valuable Player, put them back in front with one minute four seconds of the game remaining.

Buffalo were the pre-season Super Bowl favourites but have had to hit the road in the play-offs having failed to retain the AFC East title, while Jacksonville won the AFC South.

The Jaguars ended the regular season on an eight-game winning streak to secure the AFC's third seed, while Buffalo are the sixth, and most of Sunday's Wildcard Weekend game was a tight affair.

Buffalo led 10-7 at half-time, then 13-10 heading into the fourth quarter, when the lead changed hands four times in a nerve-racking finale.

Quarterbacks Trevor Lawrence and Allen then produced a shootout, with former number one draft pick Lawrence making touchdown passes to Parker Washington and Travis Etienne.

Buffalo replied with Allen finding Dalton Kincaid for a score before barging over for his second rushing TD, which ultimately proved decisive.

There was enough time for Lawrence to lead a game-winning drive but he was picked off by Bishop to keep alive Allen's hopes of reaching his first Super Bowl.

This season could be his best chance yet to reach the NFL's championship game as the Kansas City Chiefs, who knocked Buffalo out in four of the past five years, have failed to reach this season's play-offs.

title: Browns led NFL in one crazy stat that bodes well for their future
description: While the Browns only won five games in 2025, this one key stat may just prove for a brighter future in Cleveland.
fullText:
The Cleveland Browns may have only won five games in 2025, but they may not be far off, and their future is bright.

As the NFL wildcard weekend continues, ESPN showed a graphic on the youngest wide receivers in the NFL, and the Browns led the league in one key statistic. What was that statistic?

They led the NFL in snaps played by a rookie, and they led it by a landslide. According to ESPN, the Browns had 5,971 snaps played by a rookie in 2025. This was the most by over 600 snaps played. The New York Jets were second on the list with 5,327 snaps played by a rookie this past season.

This makes sense when considering that rookie quarterbacks started most of the season for the Browns, a rookie led them in rushing and receiving, their starting middle linebacker was a rookie, as was one of their starting defensive tackles. The rookies played well this season, and that bodes well for the future of the franchise.

‚Äî Mike Kadlick (@mikekadlick) January 11, 2026

Just look at the Patriots. They are in their second season after landing a quarterback in the 2024 NFL Draft. They did not even start him right away and gave him an on-ramp to the field as a rookie. Now, they are AFC East champs and are in contention for a Super Bowl after winning 14 games.

Of course, the key difference between the Browns and the Patriots right now is that the Browns are still hunting for their quarterback of the future. Well, and a head coach.

This article originally appeared on Browns Wire: Browns led NFL in one crazy stat that bodes well for their future

title: Jaguars vs. Bills radio coverage: Station, channel, streaming to listen live to NFL wild card playoff game broadcast
description: Josh Allen and the Bills travel south to face Trevor Lawrence and the Jaguars in a highly-anticipated playoff matchup.
fullText:
Jaguars vs. Bills radio coverage: Station, channel, streaming to listen live to NFL wild card playoff game broadcast originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The AFC wild card round delivers one of the most exciting quarterback showdowns of the weekend as Josh Allen and the Buffalo Bills (12-5, No. 6 seed) travel south to EverBank Stadium to face Trevor Lawrence and the AFC South Champion Jacksonville Jaguars (13-4, No. 3 seed).

This game pits two of the league's premier signal-callers against each other for the right to advance. While Allen and the Bills bring years of deep playoff experience, they will have to contend with a red-hot Jaguars team that hasn't lost since early November and enters the postseason carrying an impressive eight-game winning streak.

The wild card tilt carries a fascinating historical footnote as well: the Jaguars are 2-0 all-time against the Bills in the playoffs, securing wins in the 1996 and 2017 Wild Card rounds. However, this is a completely different era, defined by the dynamic, explosive offenses led by superstar quarterbacks. Lawrence, in particular, has elevated his game down the stretch, leading the AFC's hottest team with an MVP-caliber run through the second half of the season, a stretch that saw the Jaguars averaging 34 points per game.

The Buffalo Bills, despite being the lower seed and playing on the road for the first time in the wild card round since 2019, are looking to finally reach the Super Bowl; with the reigning MVP Josh Allen at the helm.

title: Bo Nix and Broncos are 'battle-tested' going into NFL playoffs
description: "As a team, we are battle-tested. We are strong as a unit and it showed over the whole season," Broncos CB Pat Surtain said.
fullText:
The Denver Broncos now know what to expect in a playoff atmosphere. This time, they have an edge: home-field advantage and the full force of the Mile High faithful (and thin air!) behind them. And they are ready.

Denver played a lot of close games this season, which could help them come the playoffs, where most of the games come down to just a few plays. Quarterback Bo Nix talked about how this could help them in January.

‚ÄúI think we‚Äôve been fortunate this year to play in a lot of close games and we‚Äôve won a lot of close games," said Nix. "It hasn‚Äôt been the pretty‚Ä¶ The ones that you want. The flashy, big-time wins. The ones where you get to go over there and sit, rest a little bit in the fourth [quarter]. It‚Äôs part of it. Sometimes you have to go and play the tough ones. It‚Äôs better to win some of these tough ones than lose them, obviously, for our position. It has put us in a position to understand what winning football is like. We‚Äôve played a lot of playoff teams in these tough situations."

Some of the playoff teams the Broncos have faced this year include the Los Angeles Chargers, Philadelphia Eagles, Houston Texans, Green Bay Packers and the Jacksonville Jaguars. The Broncos went 4-2 in those games, with two of those wins and one loss being a one-score game; three games (Denver played two against the Chargers) were more than one score, and the Broncos went 2-1 in those games.

"A lot of them have felt a little bit what physical, competitive football feels like," Nix said. "A lot of guys fighting for a seed or fighting to get in the tournament in general. I think it‚Äôll help us. It definitely won‚Äôt hurt us. It‚Äôll give us the experience and speed up the experience for some of the young guys like myself [to] give us the best chance to hopefully go in here and understand how to win some of these games.‚Äù

Cornerback Pat Surtain also spoke about the playoff atmospheres Denver has been in this year.

‚ÄúWe had some playoff atmospheres this year where we had some adversity early on in the game and we find a way to bounce back and finish games," said Surtain. "I feel like we are definitely battle-tested in that regard and we always find ways to win. Just in the playoffs, though, we can‚Äôt find ourselves shooting ourselves in the foot consistently. We have to find ways to really dominate and find ways to get a faster start. I think that‚Äôs what we need to focus on moving forward. As a team, we are battle-tested. We are strong as a unit and it showed over the whole season.‚Äù

Denver's battle-readiness will be tested when they face their next opponent at Mile High in the divisional round.

Social: Follow¬†Broncos Wire¬†on¬†Facebook¬†and¬†Twitter/X!¬†Did you know:¬†These 25 celebrities are Broncos fans.

title: Chiefs star reacts to Commanders interviewing Kansas City assistant
description: One of the NFL's top defensive stars reacts to the Commanders interviewing his position coach.
fullText:
The Washington Commanders are looking for a new defensive coordinator. Washington fired Joe Whitt Jr. last week after two seasons. It was a move that became inevitable when head coach Dan Quinn stripped Whitt of defensive play-calling duties ahead of Week 11.

The Commanders hired a new offensive coordinator on Friday, promoting assistant quarterbacks coach David Blough. Don't expect Washington to promote an internal candidate for defensive coordinator.

The Commanders have interviewed three known candidates thus far. One of those candidates drew the attention of one of the NFL's top defensive stars.

One of the three known interviews is Chiefs' defensive line coach Joe Cullen. Considered one of the league's top defensive line coaches, Cullen has been with the Chiefs since 2022. When ESPN's Adam Schefter revealed that Cullen had interviewed with Washington, star defensive tackle Chris Jones had an interesting reaction on X.

Oh sh!+‚Ä¶‚Ä¶. https://t.co/8b0bG5pSpR

‚Äî Chris Jones (@StoneColdJones) January 9, 2026

That reaction would seem to indicate that Jones doesn't want to see Cullen leave Kansas City. Of course, who really knows?

Cullen, a former college nose guard at UMass, has been a coach since 1990. He's been an NFL assistant since 2006, working with multiple teams as the defensive line coach. He's been an NFL coordinator once before, albeit briefly. During Urban Meyer's forgettable NFL career, Cullen served as his defensive coordinator in 2021.

The Commanders have the No. 7 overall pick in the 2026 NFL Draft and badly need a pass rusher. Could Cullen be the guy to mentor Washington's first-round pick?

This article originally appeared on Commanders Wire: Washington Commanders: Chiefs star Chris Jones reacts to DC search

title: NFL world reacts to Bears' stunning comeback win over Packers
description: The Bears mounted an unbelievable comeback against the Packers to win their wild card matchup. Here is how social media reacted to the win.
fullText:
The Chicago Bears continue to prove that they like to hibernate, but they do not die. After having six comeback wins in the regular season, they capped off yet another one in their postseason matchup against the Green Bay Packers, winning 31-27 in a stunning comeback victory to advance to the divisional round of the playoffs.

Things looked bleak early, as the Bears fell behind 21-3 in the first half after Jordan Love threw three touchdown passes. The Bears offense sputtered too many times and failed to convert on multiple fourth downs as faith in the defense was at an all-time low. Things looked bleak, but the team didn't lose hope.

Quarterback Caleb Williams and the defense rallied in the second half to turn the momentum, scoring 28 points to storm back and retake the lead. Key passes to Colston Loveland, DJ Moore, and Rome Odunze kept drives alive as the Bears took control of the game from the Packers. After Williams found Moore for the go-ahead score late in the fourth quarter, the Packers were unable to mount one more scoring drive.

It was the craziest comeback victory in a season full of them, and the NFL world took notice. Here is how social media reacted to the victory.

title: Bears & Rams claim thrilling NFL play-off wins
description: The NFL play-offs get off to a thrilling start as the Chicago Bears make a stunning fightback and the Los Angeles Rams avoid a huge upset on Wildcard Weekend.

title: Bears score 25 points in epic final-quarter comeback to beat Packers
description: The NFL play-offs get off to a thrilling start as the Chicago Bears make a stunning fightback and the Los Angeles Rams avoid a huge upset on Wildcard Weekend.
fullText:
The Chicago Bears produced a stunning fightback to beat divisional rivals Green Bay and claim their first play-off win in 15 years.

The Bears managed a record six comebacks in the regular season having trailed inside the final two minutes and they pulled off another escape act to beat the Packers 31-27 in Chicago.

Green Bay led for most of Saturday's Wildcard Weekend game but Chicago scored 25 points in the fourth quarter to recover from an 18-point deficit - a franchise record for the post-season.

The Bears follow the Los Angeles Rams into the Divisional Round after they avoided a huge upset at the Carolina Panthers, with Colby Parkinson's touchdown giving them a 34-31 win with 38 seconds remaining.

title: Panthers 2026 NFL Draft order: 1st-round pick finalized with playoffs exit
description: It was delayed by a week, but the Panthers are officially on to the offseason after being eliminated by the Rams in the Wild Card Round of the 2026 playoffs. Carolina‚Äôs draft position is now locked into place at No. 19. The rest of the teams that lose this weekend will fill in slots 20-24. [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
It was delayed by a week, but the Panthers are officially on to the offseason after being eliminated by the Rams in the Wild Card Round of the 2026 playoffs. Carolina‚Äôs draft position is now locked into place at No. 19. The rest of the teams that lose this weekend will fill in slots 20-24.

Carolina ranked near the bottom of the NFL in 2026 in sacks with 30, and edge rusher is absolutely a top need heading into free agency and the draft. Rico Dowdle was the team‚Äôs leading rusher, with 1,076 yards and six rushing touchdowns, plus contributed 297 receiving yards and a touchdown through the air, and he‚Äôs hitting free agency. Christian Rozeboom, the Panthers‚Äô tackles leader who also had two sacks, three pass break-ups, a pick and a forced fumble, will also become a free agent when the new league year ends. The Panthers are projected to have about $39 million in cap space to work with this offseason based on the 51-man projection, but obviously when they can shore up these key positions through the draft, it makes long-term team building for success easier.

Here‚Äôs the updated draft order after the Panthers‚Äô Wild Card exit.

Los Angeles Rams (via Atlanta Falcons)

New York Jets (via Indianapolis Colts)

Dallas Cowboys (via Green Bay Packers)

Cleveland Browns (via Jacksonville Jaguars)

title: Where to watch NFL Wild Card Games: Live stream Packers, Bears, and more
description: The NFL Playoffs begin with six Wild Card games. We'll show you how to live stream every match-up online.
fullText:
The NFL playoffs have arrived, and 12 teams will duke it out in Wild Card games for a shot at the Divisional round. We've gathered everything you need to know about where to watch NFL Wild Card games, including live streaming options.

The Denver Broncos and Seattle Seahawks earned first-round byes, but the other 12 teams to make it to the postseason will battle it out in one of six Wild Card games. The NFC will see Los Angeles Rams vs. Carolina Panthers, Green Bay Packers vs. Chicago Bears, and San Francisco 49ers vs. Philadelphia Eagles showdowns. The AFC will feature Buffalo Bills vs. Jacksonville Jaguars, Los Angeles Chargers vs. New England Patriots, and Houston Texans vs. Pittsburgh Steelers games.

The most notable omission in this year's postseason lineup is the Kansas City Chiefs, who haven't missed the playoffs in several years and made it all the way to the Super Bowl for five out of the six past seasons. The Chiefs faced a tricky couple of months and ultimately lost their star quarterback, Patrick Mahomes, to a season-ending knee injury in mid-December.

Whether the Eagles, the reigning champions, can go all the way again this year or whether there will be two fresh teams at Super Bowl LX remains to be seen. Keep reading to learn some of the best ways to tune into the Wild Card round, including global streaming options.

The NFL Wild Card games are spread across several networks and streaming services in the US, including Prime Video, CBS, FOX, NBC, and ESPN. Each network has its own streaming counterpart, which we'll dig into below, but if you're looking to watch every game (other than the streaming exclusive Prime Video match-up) in one place, then a live TV streaming service will be able to help you out.

The Chargers vs. Patriots game will air on NBC. Cord-cutters can live stream the game through Peacock. While you typically need Peacock Premium Plus ($17 a month) to unlock NBC live streaming, you're able to watch NFL games with the Peacock Premium ($11 a month) tier.

Peacock is a convenient streaming source for hit NBC TV shows, Universal movies, and select sports like Sunday Night Football. The service also carries its own slate of original programming.

The Texans vs. Steelers game will air on both ESPN and ABC. ESPN's direct streaming counterpart is ESPN Unlimited, which costs $30 a month. While the cheaper ESPN Select tier unlocks some action, you'll need to opt for the Unlimited plan to watch this game.

ESPN Unlimited has everything from ESPN Plus, in addition to all that the ESPN linear networks have to offer.

The Rams vs. Panthers and 49ers vs. Eagles games will air on FOX. FOX's direct streaming counterpart is FOX One, which starts at $20 a month and comes with a seven-day free trial.

All games will also be available through NFL Plus, where subscriptions start at $7 a month (or $15 a month for Premium). However, games are only available on mobile devices, like cell phones and tablets, so we recommend one of the above streaming services if you'd like to watch the games on a TV. There's also an opportunity to bundle NFL Plus Premium with ESPN Unlimited for $40 a month, a reduced rate compared to subscribing to each service separately.

NFL fans in the UK and other regions can watch every game through DAZN's NFL Game Pass. Subscriptions prices vary by region and plan, but the streaming service will host the entirety of the NFL postseason, including the Super Bowl.

DAZN is the home of NFL Game Pass International, the only service offering live and on-demand access to all NFL games in supported countries outside the United States and China.

Football fans don't need to worry about missing out on any of the action just because they're traveling away from home. title: NFL Playoffs‚Äô overtime rules, explained for 2026 postseason
description: probably know the story. A thrilling AFC Divisional Round game between the Kansas City Chiefs and the Buffalo Bills at the end of the 2021-2022 NFL season led the league to change the overtime rules for playoff games, giving both teams a chance to possess the football. Previously, the team that won [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
A thrilling AFC Divisional Round game between the Kansas City Chiefs and the Buffalo Bills at the end of the 2021-2022 NFL season led the league to change the overtime rules for playoff games, giving both teams a chance to possess the football. Previously, the team that won the coin toss could elect to receive the kick, and would win the game with a touchdown on their first drive.

The outcry after Josh Allen and the Bills lost that playoff game without getting a chance to touch the football in overtime led to the revised rules.

So as the 2025-2026 NFL Playoffs get ready to begin, let‚Äôs revisit those rules, because you never know when you will need to know them.

All playoff games that advance to overtime will follow these revised rules:

If a game is tied at the end of regulation, the referee will toss a coin to determine which team will possess the ball first in overtime. The visiting team captain will call the toss.

Both teams will have an opportunity to possess the football. This is the big change. Previously, as we saw in the 2022 AFC Divisional Round game between Kansas City and Buffalo, if the team that started with the football scored a touchdown, the game was over. Under the new rules, in that scenario, Buffalo would get a chance to match with a touchdown of their own, and if they did, the game would continue. Once both teams have had possession, the game then becomes sudden death. In addition, if the team that starts with possession scores and kicks the extra point to take a seven-point lead, the second team can win with a touchdown and a two-point conversion.

If the score is still tied at the end of an overtime period ‚Äî or if the second team‚Äôs initial possession is still in progress ‚Äî the teams will play another overtime period. Play will continue regardless of how many overtime periods are needed for a winner to be determined.

There will be a two-minute intermission between each overtime period. There will not be a halftime intermission after the second period.

If the game remains tied after two overtime periods, there will be a second half. The captain who lost the first overtime coin toss will either choose to possess the ball or select which goal his team will defend unless the team that won the coin toss deferred that choice.

Each team gets three timeouts during a half.

The same timing rules that apply at the end of the second and fourth regulation periods also apply at the end of a second or fourth overtime period.

If there is still no winner at the end of a fourth overtime period, there will be a third coin toss, and play will continue until a winner is declared.

There are no instant replay coach‚Äôs challenges; all reviews will be initiated by the replay official.

Super Bowl LVIII made a little history under the revised playoff rules.

Super Bowl LVIII became the first playoff game under the league‚Äôs new overtime rules for the postseason, and those changes guaranteed each team a chance to possess the football in overtime. After the San Francisco 49ers kicked a field goal ‚Äî more on that in a moment ‚Äî Patrick Mahomes and the Kansas City Chiefs drove down the field and scored the game-winning touchdown on the final play of Super Bowl LVIII.

That made Super Bowl LVIII the first Super Bowl to see a lead change on the final play of the game.

Looking back at how that unfolded, many wonder if the 49ers should have approached things differently.

San Francisco won the coin toss, and made the decision to receive the kickoff, despite a prevailing theory that under the new rules it made more sense to defer. With both teams guaranteed a possession, knowing what you need to score to win the game offers a competitive advantage, similar to how teams in college want to start on defense in overtime, so they know what they need to do on offense to win.

Instead, the 49ers began on offense, and could only manage a field goal. That opened the door for the Chiefs to win the game on their guaranteed possession with a touchdown, which is exactly what they did.

Speaking after the game, San Francisco head coach Kyle Shanahan stated that the team had run through the various scenarios, and thought by starting on offense they would have the advantage if the game advanced to a third overtime possession, and sudden death.

‚ÄúNone of us have a ton of experience with it,‚Äù Shanahan said. ‚ÄúWe went through all the analytics and talked to those guys. We decided it would be better getting the ball because if both teams matched and scored, we wanted to be the ones to have a chance to go win it.‚Äù

The problem? The game never got to that third overtime.

Last year, none of the playoff games advanced to overtime, so fans were not treated to another situation like Super Bowl LVIII.

Nor did they get a chance to see what, if anything, teams and coaches learned from how that game ended.

Ahead of the 2025 NFL season, the league decided to align the overtime rules for the regular season with the approach for the playoffs. However, that change was made ‚Äúsubject to a 10-minute overtime period in the regular season.‚Äù

Meaning regular season games could still end in ties, unlike postseason games.

Lessons learned from Super Bowl LVIII seemed to come into play during overtime periods in the regular season. One example comes from when the Green Bay Packers and the Dallas Cowboys went to overtime back in September. Green Bay won the coin toss ahead of overtime but elected to kick, since they were now guaranteed a possession even if Dallas scored a touchdown.

Green Bay held Dallas to a field goal, giving the Packers a chance to win the game with a touchdown. But when their drive stalled deep in Cowboys‚Äô territory, Green Bay was forced to settle for a game-tying field goal.

Other example from this past regular season indicate that teams will defer in overtime under the new rules. In October the San Francisco 49ers and the Los Angeles Rams went to overtime, with Los Angeles winning the coin toss. Sean McVay and the Rams chose to kick, giving the 49ers possession first.

San Francisco settled for a field goal, but the Rams were stopped on 4th-and-1 to end the game.

In November the Carolina Panthers and the Atlanta Falcons went to overtime, with Carolina winning the toss. Quarterback Bryce Young declared ‚Äúwe want to kick that way,‚Äù which was incorrectly granted by the referee. A team can choose to kick, or which end zone to defend, but they cannot choose both.

But the Panthers indeed started on defense, forced a punt, and then kicked a game-winning field goal on the next drive.

One scenario that has not been tested yet? The impact of the two-point conversion. After Super Bowl LVIII Kansas City indicated that if necessary, they would have gone for two at the end of their possession to try and win, rather than kick an extra point and extend the game to a third overtime possession.

Should overtime arise in this year‚Äôs playoffs, will the two-point conversion come into play?

I guess we will have to wait to find out.

title: Future Broncos: Pathways to approach the 2026 NFL Draft
description: The Denver Broncos have a quality roster which gives them ultimate flexibility in approaching the 2026 NFL Draft.
fullText:
The Denver Broncos finished their 2025 regular season with a 14-3 record, an AFC West title, and a first-round bye. Today, six members of the team were announced to have earned All-Pro honors. It‚Äôs been a long time since the Broncos have had a roster this strong. A big tip of the cap to Head Coach Sean Payton, General Manager George Paton, and the pro and collegiate scouts for helping reforge this roster in relatively short order despite significant limitations due to the implications of the failed Russell Wilson era.

With second-year signal caller Bo Nix on a rookie contract, ample cap space with the ability to create more, and at least five picks in the top four rounds, the Broncos certainly have great flexibility in how they approach the 2026 NFL Draft. However, what the Broncos eventually do come late April will be highly dependent on what happens in free agency.

As of now, several defensive starters or players who earned meaningful snap time are scheduled to be unrestricted free agents. Alex Singleton and Justin Strnad at inside linebacker, John Franklin-Myers at defensive end, and safety P.J. Locke. Another significant contributor, standout nickelback Ja‚ÄôQuan McMillian, is scheduled to be a restricted free agent. I‚Äôd expect the Broncos to tender him at least at a second-round level which would give him a big pay raise next season.

Additional #Broncos to get All-Pro votes:

FB Adam Prentice
WR Courtland Sutton
LG Alex Palczewski
RT Mike McGlinchey
OLB Nik Bonitto
CB Ja'Quan McMillian
PR Marvin Mims Jr.
LS Mitchell Fraboni

‚Äî Aric DiLalla (@AricDiLalla) January 10, 2026

If Defensive Coordinator Vance Joseph winds up being hired for one of the head coaching positions available, it‚Äôs safe to say there could be some big roster changes pending who the new defensive coordinator would be. I‚Äôd assume that would be Assistant Head Coach and Passing Game Coordinator Jim Leonhard, who is widely regarded as a rising star in the coaching community.

Keeping him in the fold would likely allow for a smoother transition, opting to keep a lot of the same verbiage in place, but adding some more of his unique wrinkles and personalities into the mix defensively. Given the above, it wouldn‚Äôt be a surprise to see the Broncos once again opt to utilize their first-round selection on the defensive side of the ball. Inside linebacker, unless they sign someone in free agency, seems like the easiest position on the roster where you could find a quality return on investment and immediate impact from a draft prospect.

For those of you who have followed Future Broncos segments this year‚Äîyou all know it‚Äôs one of the better off-ball linebacker classes in ages. The Ohio State duo of Arvell Reese and Sonny Styles played tremendously this season and will likely both be Top 15 selections. Though Texas standout Anthony Hill Jr. and Georgia star CJ Allen would very well be in play for the Broncos where they are currently slated to pick. Either of those two would be phenomenal selections that would definitely brighten Denver‚Äôs long-term future at the position.

Texas LB Anthony Hill Jr. will enter the 2026 NFL Draft.

Hill is a projected day 2 draft pick. pic.twitter.com/x6pxGkoluW

‚Äî Dane Brugler (@dpbrugler) December 8, 2025

The Broncos will pick no earlier than 25th overall pending a move up the boards in April. If Joseph is hired by another team as I discussed above, that would give the Broncos a third-round compensatory selection and six selections in the top 150 selections. That‚Äôs a lot of draft capital to round out the roster and address future needs.

I‚Äôd expect the Broncos to continue their trend of focusing on the trenches. It‚Äôs been a premium point of investment since Payton was hired. Garett Bolles and Mike McGlinchey played great this season, but they aren‚Äôt getting any younger and it‚Äôs been ages since Denver has opted to invest in drafting a tackle. With extra early round selections, I would like to see that finally happen. If Franklin-Myers walks in free agency, finding another defensive end might be wise. Though I‚Äôll say I‚Äôve been impressed with Eyioma Uwazurike this season and think platooning him and Sai‚Äôvion Jones next year to replace Myers wouldn‚Äôt be a bad idea.

Don‚Äôt be surprised to see Denver also add some depth to their secondary. At safety, Brandon Jones and J.L. Skinner will be in the final years of their contracts in ‚Äò26. Additionally, Riley Moss and the aforementioned McMillian will be scheduled to hit free agency after next season as well. Part of the reason Jahdae Barron was selected last season was planning ahead, but the Broncos should be diligent finding another prospect with starting potential on the backend of their defense.

And of course, the Broncos‚Äô offense could always use more playmakers. Whether it‚Äôs running back, tight end, or wide receiver‚Äîraising the floor and long-term prospects of all those position groups would be wise. With extra picks on hand, finding a way to surround Nix with more talent would be a smart call.

What do you think, Broncos Country? Do you have an early philosophy for Denver‚Äôs 2026 NFL Draft approach? Are there any particular players you are banging the table for with their first-round pick? Sound off in the comments and let me know.

title: Florida mom of three killed by husband over NFL game 'died a hero'
description: One of Crystal Roure's last acts alive was to tell her 12-year-old son to get out of the house and call 911. Her family believes it saved his life.
fullText:
As a single mom, Crystal Roure was fiercely protective of her children.

So when she started dating a handsome man from church, Crystal didn‚Äôt introduce him right away. In fact, she waited until they had dated for a full year before he met the kids.

‚ÄúShe took her time," Crystal's sister, Stephanie Roure, told USA TODAY this week. "She did have a happy glow that I haven't seen in a long time ... My sister trusted him and fell in love with him. She finally found her happy ever after."

But on Dec. 22, just two years after Crystal married Jason Kenney, he would end up killing her and shooting her 13-year-old daughter in the face in their Florida home ‚àí all over an argument about watching a football game three days before Christmas, according to the Polk County Sheriff's Office. Kenney later fatally shot himself.

The crime during the December holidays shocked the nation.

‚ÄúThe 13-year-old girl begged not to be shot ‚Äì ‚ÄòPlease don't shoot me. Please don't shoot me,‚Äô‚Äù Polk County Sheriff Grady Judd said at a news conference the week of the attack. ‚ÄúAnd he shot her twice.‚Äù

Now as Crystal's family reels from grief and shock, USA TODAY is telling her story and how she used her final moments alive to save her children.

From an early age, Crystal Roure showed ambition and a commitment to hard work.

Her sister Stephanie recalled how Crystal did well in school and thrived when she got her first job at T.G.I. Friday's as a teenager, quickly graduating from hostess to server.

"What set her apart from others was she didn't just work for a paycheck ... she worked for the experience," Stephanie said. "She worked for the knowledge. She worked to prove to herself she was able to do things and not give up."

But when she became a mom at the age of 25, "everything she did from that moment on was for her children."

"She worked harder and longer," Stephanie said. "And somehow she was superwoman. She managed to hold down a full-time job and being a full-time mother."

Though Crystal had to juggle work and the kids all while being single, she didn't miss a school function, award ceremony or field trip. She also managed to buy a house all on her own, "because she was a smart woman," Stephanie said.

"Her children were her world. She worked hard for them, to provide for them. She protected them," she said. "They came first before anything."

Early in the relationship, Facebook photos show the pair smiling and kissing each other in many selfies. Other show them and the kids looking like a picture-perfect family, posing in front of a Christmas tree and at a baseball game.

But sometime after they married on Nov. 4, 2023, Stephanie said: "My sister lost that glow she had."

At first, Stephanie chalked up the change to the fact that Crystal became pregnant with her third child pretty quickly after the wedding.

"I remember asking her, 'Are you OK?'" Stephanie said. "She said, 'Yes,' it's just this pregnancy was really kicking her butt because she was much older."

Though Stephanie said she always had an "ehh" feeling about Kenney, she thought her sister was happy and safe.

That is until she got the worst phone call of her life.

Crystal and her three kids spent the evening of Dec. 22 by the Christmas tree at their home in Highland City, just east of Tampa. Meanwhile Kenney was in his shed, drinking and watching Monday Night Football until about 11 p.m., Sheriff Judd said.

When Kenney went inside the home and wanted to continue watching the game, a fight ensued. It became so scary that Crystal told her 12-year-old son to run to a neighbor's house and call 911, Judd said.

As the boy ran out, he heard the first gunshot. Responding deputies found Crystal dead inside, her 13-year-old daughter shot in the face and shoulder, and Jason Kenney gone. They also found a letter Crystal wrote to her husband telling him: "You're drinking, you‚Äôre¬†using cocaine¬†again. This is not the way the family should be. You need God."

The 1-year-old daughter the couple shared was unharmed. The 13-year-old survived the gunshot wound after the bullet hit the bridge of her nose and deflected through the top of her head, Judd said.

After shooting his wife and step-daughter, Kenney drove in his truck to his late father's home and called his sister to say he had "done something very, very bad" and that it was the last time they would ever talk, Judd said.

Deputies tracked Kenney down to a shed on his father's property. When they called for him to come out, they heard a single gunshot and found Kenney dead inside.

Judd said that a relative told deputies that Kenney had been beating on Crystal "for a while," though the sheriff's office has no records of any domestic violence calls or charges. Jason Kenney had no criminal history, Judd said.

"He absolutely destroyed a family," Judd said. "When you go in there, there is a beautiful Christmas tree with lots of Christmas presents under the tree, just like the nuclear family should be ... and it ends up this way."

Crystal's family is leaning on each other as they absorb the shock of her murder and raising funds for the children. Crystal's 13-year-old daughter "is doing well on her recovery" and "it really is a miracle that the bullet missed every major thing," Stephanie said.

As for any abuse leading up to the tragedy, Stephanie said it's possible but she wasn't aware of any.

"After they were married I know she said he was drinking a lot more but she said that he was going to stop and said he would get help with it. Obviously that didn't happen," she said, adding that when she went over to visit, Kenney would "sit outside in the shed playing games on his phone and smoking his cigarettes."

"If there was abuse happening he must have scared her to the point not to say or do anything because the type of person my sister was she would have left at the first sight of trouble because she would protect her kids," she said. "But that's a question we'll never have answers to."

Stephanie said she's angry that Kenney killed her sister and tried to kill her niece but that she's so proud of Crystal and her nephew's actions that night.

"My sister died a hero for protecting her children and getting my nephew out of the house to make the 911 call," she said. "She did that. She saved their lives and by doing so my nephew saved his sister's life, and thank God the baby was untouched."

Stephanie said she is going to do her best to teach her 1-year-old niece all about who her mom was.

"I will never let these kids forget the love and strength and courage she had for them," she said. "They will always know that she loved them and put them first."

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Florida mom of three killed by husband over NFL game 'died a hero'

title: NFL Wild Card Weekend Longshot Bets: Underdogs, Props & High-Payout Plays
description: Looking for value this postseason? We break down the best NFL Wild Card Weekend longshot bets, including underdogs, prop plays, and high-payout angles.
fullText:
Super Wild Card Weekend in the NFL is built for chaos ‚Äî and chaos creates opportunity for bettors willing to chase longshot value.

Our experts have identified four longshot NFL picks with the potential to boost your ROI as three straight days of knockout football take center stage.

Trevor Lawrence 3+ passing TDs (+350 at FanDuel)

Tommy Tremble anytime TD (+650 at FanDuel)

Dalton Schultz first TD (+850 at FanDuel)

Each team to score 1+ rushing touchdown (+12500 at FanDuel)

Trevor Lawrence 3+ passing touchdowns (+350)

Trevor Lawrence has thrown three or more scores in three of his last four games. He‚Äôs also piled up 10 passing TDs over his last three home starts, with this pass-catching group playing its best football of the season.

Parker Washington has 347 yards over the last three games, Jakobi Meyers continues to move the chains, and Brian Thomas remains a matchup problem. Add in Brenton Strange and Travis Etienne as a receiving threat, and there are plenty of ways for this offense to score.

The Buffalo Bills are banged up in the secondary, with rookie Maxwell Hairston out and Jordan Poyer questionable, plus linebacker Terrel Bernard missing practice. If the Bills sell out to stop the run, Lawrence should be forced to throw ‚Äî and that sets up well for another strong passing day.

Tommy Tremble anytime TD (+650)

This is a massive price for a clear-cut TE1 on a team that should be throwing more than usual as a double-digit home underdog.

In his first game without Ja‚ÄôTavion Sanders, Tremble stepped into the TE1 role and caught three of four targets for 38 yards and a TD at +500. Tommy Tremble ranked third in route share and logged a 90% snap rate, second among pass catchers.

He‚Äôs clearly involved yet priced like a TE2 with minimal usage. With Sanders still on IR, this should be closer to +300 or +330.

After missing Week 18, Nico Collins returns to the Texans' lineup on Monday. But even with their star wideout back, we still need to consider tight end Dalton Schultz a live option to score the opener against the Steelers.

He‚Äôs only scored three times all season, but two of those have come in the past month. He ranks second on the Texans roster in red-zone targets across the year.

With the Steelers giving up 11 touchdowns to TEs this season, tied for third-most in the league, it could be a good Monday for the former Stanford man.

Each team to score 1+ rushing TD (+12500)

title: Pat Surtain says Broncos feel 'very dangerous' going into NFL playoffs

fullText:
The Denver Broncos secured the No. 1 seed in the AFC playoffs after going 14-3 in the regular season. They now enter the NFL playoffs, and there's no room for error in the win-or-go-home format.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a mindset, I believe," cornerback Pat Surtain said when asked what changes for a player in the playoffs. "We all realize in a tournament it‚Äôs do or die. It‚Äôs really almost zero margin of error once you‚Äôre in the tournament. We feel like, as a team we have a lot to correct and a lot to adjust, but at the end of the day, we are glad we have home-field advantage. You need as much of an advantage going into the playoffs. That‚Äôs a huge part of it, securing the No. 1 seed and getting home-field advantage. That‚Äôs big time for us. I feel like we aren‚Äôt a finished product. We aren‚Äôt where we want to be yet. Like I said before, I feel like we are very dangerous knowing that we have home-field advantage right in front of us.‚Äù

title: Are the NFL's overtime rules needlessly complex?
description: NFL overtime was supposed to make games fairer.  Overtime still begins with a coin toss, and the winner isn‚Äôt just choosing who gets the ball ‚Äî they can also choose to defer or even pick which end of the field to defend.  Under the current system, both teams are guaranteed at least one possession, even if the team that receives the opening kickoff scores a touchdown.
fullText:
Are the NFL's overtime rules needlessly complex? originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

NFL overtime was supposed to make games fairer. Instead, it has become one of the most confusing and overbuilt systems in professional sports ‚Äî especially in the playoffs, where the rules quietly change again and grow even more complicated.

What should be a simple extension of the game now feels like a rulebook within the rulebook.

Overtime still begins with a coin toss, and the winner isn‚Äôt just choosing who gets the ball ‚Äî they can also choose to defer or even pick which end of the field to defend. Before a single snap is played, layers of strategy and technicalities are already in motion.

Under the current system, both teams are guaranteed at least one possession, even if the team that receives the opening kickoff scores a touchdown. That team must then kick off and allow the opponent a chance to respond. The only way the game can end immediately is if the defense scores a safety on the opening possession ‚Äî another rare and oddly specific exception that fans must remember.

The postseason adds even more complexity. Overtime periods are 15 minutes instead of 10. If a team‚Äôs guaranteed possession is still ongoing when time expires, it simply carries over into another overtime period. The game is treated like a continuation of regulation, complete with three timeouts per team, two-minute warnings, and end-of-half clock rules. If the game remains tied, teams line up for yet another kickoff, with only a brief two-minute ‚Äúhalftime‚Äù if a second overtime is reached. And in the extremely unlikely event that four overtime periods are played, another coin toss resets the format yet again.

All of this exists in the name of fairness ‚Äî but fairness has slowly been confused with overcorrection.

The NFL has rewritten its overtime rules multiple times over the years, most notably after Josh Allen never touched the ball in the Bills‚Äô playoff loss to the Chiefs. That game sparked the guaranteed-possession rule, fundamentally changing overtime strategy. But in doing so, the league didn‚Äôt just tweak a flaw ‚Äî it created a system that increasingly minimizes the need to actually play defense. Now, if you win the toss and have a capable offense, you‚Äôre almost guaranteed to at least extend the game, regardless of whether your defense can get a stop.

At some point, the league has to ask whether it‚Äôs designing rules for competition ‚Äî or designing them around star players who feel they were wronged.

If the NFL is going to adjust overtime every time a high-profile quarterback is unhappy with how a season ended, it might as well take the next logical step and adopt the NCAA overtime model. College football‚Äôs system is cleaner. It‚Äôs clearer. And most importantly, it‚Äôs more exciting. Both teams know exactly what they‚Äôre getting: equal opportunities, immediate pressure, and a true test of execution in scoring situations.

Football thrives on simplicity ‚Äî move the ball, stop the ball, score more points, win the game. The current NFL overtime system has drifted far from that. What was meant to be fair has become bloated, confusing, and increasingly disconnected from the core of the sport. If overtime is going to feel this manufactured anyway, the league may as well choose a model that fans can actually understand ‚Äî and enjoy.

Former Denver Broncos linebacker Von Miller isn‚Äôt ready to slow down. Earlier Friday, he said he wants to keep playing so he can continue climbing the NFL‚Äôs all-time sacks list.

title: Oregon QB Dante Moore not sure about NFL Draft decision after 3-turnover night vs. Indiana
description: The redshirt sophomore was projected to go second overall to the Jets in the 2026 NFL Draft. The Peach Bowl didn't help his stock.
fullText:
The College Football Playoff semifinal at the Peach Bowl was a clash between No. 5 Oregon and No. 1 Indiana. It was also a clash between the No. 1 and No. 2 picks of Yahoo Sports' latest NFL mock draft.

In both cases, it's pretty safe to say who came out on top.

Indiana reached the national title game with a 56-22 demolishing of the Ducks, taking a four-touchdown lead into halftime and coasting from there. Hoosiers quarterback Fernando Mendoza, the favorite to be the Las Vegas Raiders' first overall pick in a few months, was 17-for-20 for 177 passing yards, 5 touchdowns and 0 interceptions.

And Oregon quarterback Dante Moore, the projected second pick? He was 24-for-39 with 285 passing yards, 2 touchdowns and 3 backbreaking turnovers. It's safe to say the performance didn't help the redshirt sophomore's draft stock.

When asked about his draft decision after the game, Moore said he hadn't made a decision yet.

‚ÄúAt the end of the day, I don‚Äôt know my decision yet.‚Äù

Dante Moore on his future ‚¨áÔ∏è pic.twitter.com/W1r22EaepO

‚Äî FOX College Football (@CFBONFOX) January 10, 2026

"I'm going to soak this moment up and, most importantly, give my hugs and thank yous to my teammates. But at the end of the day, I don't know my decision yet. I'm going to talk to coach Lanning and talk to my family and everybody, but at the end of the day I don't want to think about that right now."

As of now, Moore still looms as a candidate to go second overall to the New York Jets, but his performance on Friday laid bare some concerns around his game.

After a rough freshman year at UCLA and a redshirt year under Dillon Gabriel last season, Moore had impressed all season with his arm strength, accuracy, athleticism and command of the Oregon offense. However, he was never pressured in the pocket like he was against Indiana, and the results were ugly.

‚Äî Nate Tice (@Nate_Tice) January 10, 2026

Oregon would surely welcome Moore back for a junior season and at only 20 years old, he still has plenty of time to get to the NFL. The decision is shaping up to be one of the biggest among all underclassmen in this year's draft cycle.

As for Mendoza, you can probably guess where he's going after a dream season in which he's led Indiana to a 15-0 record while winning the Heisman Trophy.

title: 2025 NFL Draft re-draft proves Saints found a steal in QB Tyler Shough
description: Where did Shough land in a re-draft of the 2025 NFL Draft?
fullText:
2025 NFL Draft re-draft proves Saints found a steal in QB Tyler Shough originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The New Orleans Saints may have a quarterback on their hands. Rookie Tyler Shough impressed in the first nine starts of his young professional career, completing 67.6% of his passes for 2,384 yards, 10 touchdowns, and six interceptions.

New Orleans was even able to win four of their last five games under the guidance of Shough, providing optimism that he can be their quarterback of the future.

In real life, Shough had to wait to have his name called until the 40th overall pick in the second round of the 2025 NFL Draft. But almost a year removed, would he be picked any higher?

In a re-draft of the 2025 NFL Draft, Bleacher Report's Brent¬†Sobleski projected Shough to go No. 3 overall to the New York Giants, since Jaxson Dart and Cam Ward were both off the board with the first two picks.

"Tyler Shough performed better than any rookie quarterback this past season. A person can even argue he should have been the No. 1 overall pick when compared to his classmates. He slides to No. 3 based on one factor: upside," wrote Sobleski.

"Aside from age, he originally fell into the second round because of an extensive injury history throughout his collegiate career. He remained healthy in 2025, but that concern hasn't disappeared."

Despite Sobleski's concerns, it's impressive that a second-round pick improved his stock enough in nine games to be considered a top-three pick just nine months later.

It's safe to say the Saints are pleased with last year's selection.

title: NFL Moneyline Picks for Every Wild Card Game
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers may have escaped elimination in Week 18, but their luck will run out on Wild Card Weekend against the red-hot Houston Texans.
fullText:
The playoffs have finally arrived, and we‚Äôre locked and loaded with six matchups spanning Saturday through Monday.

Headlined by the Houston Texans spoiling the party in Steeltown, here are my favorite moneyline NFL picks for every game during Wild Card Weekend.

Although Carolina upset Los Angeles 31‚Äì28 in Week 13, an uncharacteristic game from Matthew Stafford saw the Rams‚Äô gunslinger turn the ball over three times, including the Panthers offense going a ridiculous 3-for-3 on fourth down.

The Rams‚Äô scoring unit remains elite across all key metrics, finishing the year first in points per game (30.5), and Sean McVay won‚Äôt allow a repeat stumble at Bank of America Stadium.

Read our full Rams vs. Panthers predictions.

It‚Äôs hard to overlook Jordan Love‚Äôs playoff experience compared with Caleb Williams.

If it weren‚Äôt for Chicago‚Äôs miraculous Week 16 comeback over Green Bay, the Packers would be slight favorites ‚Äî but I‚Äôll take the Packers, who remain stronger on defense despite injuries.

Chicago‚Äôs stock is at an all-time high right now, making this a perfect time to push back against the public.

Read our full Packers vs. Bears predictions.

Get ready for a battle between the No. 1 rushing offense and the No. 1 rushing defense.

While it‚Äôs hard to ignore Josh Allen‚Äôs mastery under center, Jacksonville has won nine of its last 10 games, and Liam Coen has Trevor Lawrence playing the best football of his career.

With Buffalo remaining banged up on D, I‚Äôll side with the home team to open the Sunday slate.

San Francisco has been an incredible story, and Kyle Shanahan deserves a ton of credit for getting this injury-riddled roster to the postseason... but last week‚Äôs loss to Seattle hurt in more ways than one.

Not only did that home loss to Seattle cost them the No. 1 seed in the NFC, but starting linebacker Dee Winters is now listed as questionable after leaving the game with an ankle injury, while Tatum Bethune is done for the rest of the season (groin).

As good as the Chargers‚Äô defense has been this season, Drake Maye is going to move the ball at some point, and the Patriots faithful will be rearing to go for their first home playoff game since 2019.

Bank on Justin Herbert remaining winless in the postseason.

While Houston enters the postseason on the back of nine straight wins, the Steelers have essentially backed their way into the playoffs, barely squeaking by in Week 18 following a missed field goal at the buzzer by Baltimore kicker Tyler Loop.

Pittsburgh‚Äôs sluggish offense remains a tough watch, and the Houston Texans‚Äô vaunted pass rush will make life miserable for Aaron Rodgers.

Mike Tomlin has lost six straight playoff games dating back a decade, and another quick exit is in store on Monday.

title: Why Texans could go deep into NFL play-offs & Maye has earned MVP
description: NFL analyst Phoebe Schecter gives her predictions as this season's play-offs begin with Wildcard Weekend.
fullText:
This season's NFL play-offs begin at the weekend and here BBC columnist Phoebe Schecter gives her predictions for the six games on Wildcard Weekend.

All kick-off times GMT, Conference seed in brackets

Los Angeles Rams (5) @ Carolina Panthers (4) - 21:30

This is a rematch from week 13, but I don't think it's fair to look at that 31-28 win for the Panthers. They managed to stay alive in the play-off hunt but their defence has kind of been the reason they've stayed in most of their games, rather than their quarterback Bryce Young.

The Rams are one of the Super Bowl favourites and I think their defence is going to be the final nail in the coffin for Carolina.

Matt Stafford is one of the leading MVP contenders and Puka Nacua leads the league for receptions. He's just so physical in taking contested catches. His one-handed catches are incredible.

The Rams have struggled in the red zone in recent weeks without Davante Adams but he's set to come back so, for me, it's a clear Rams win.

Green Bay Packers (7) @ Chicago Bears (2) - 01:00 Sun

This is going to be awesome. They're divisional rivals and it's the NFL's oldest rivalry, so there's so much familiarity. That's what makes it so exciting.

They've played each other twice in the last five weeks and they're 1-1. The Packers almost beat the Bears in week 16, and that was after Micah Parsons' injury and being without Jordan Love for most of the game (concussion).

Caleb Williams is doing such a great job with his game management, his athleticism, the way the ball just jumps out of his hand, and his receivers are coming together, so I have the Bears on this one.

They have had the most fourth-quarter comebacks in a season (six) and their defence leads the league with 33 takeaways. They'll probably need to get a couple more against Jordan Love to really seal the deal.

Live text commentary on all play-off games on the BBC Sport website and app, plus live radio commentary on selected games on BBC Radio 5 Sports Extra and BBC Sounds. The Whole 10 Yards, BBC Sport's weekly NFL programme, will also follow the road to Super Bowl 60

Buffalo Bills (6) @ Jacksonville Jaguars (3) - 18:00

With Kansas City, Cincinnati and Baltimore not in the play-offs, this is the clearest route to the Super Bowl the Bills have had, but this is a scary Jags team.

They've won their last eight, so they're the team that has momentum. They're having fun out there, and we've never seen this version of Trevor Lawrence before, the way he's finishing in the red zone. He looks so confident.

The Jags have been clicking on all three phases since their bye week. They brought in Jakobi Myers and the Bills have to stop Travis Etienne running all over them.

But I still have so much faith in Josh Allen. We've seen it so many times, where he comes to life in the fourth quarter, and it's hard to bet against him. So I'm going for my Bills, especially because I'll be working at the game ‚Äì and I can't stand the thought of them losing!

San Francisco 49ers (6) @ Philadelphia Eagles (3) - 21:30

Given their injuries, coach Kyle Shanahan has been incredible to get the 49ers where they are. They have done a great job of staying afloat with their defence, but I just don't know how sustainable it is.

Having slipped from potentially the top seed to the sixth, Shanahan's been like 'we've just got to do it the hard way'. This must mean so much to them because of the 2023 NFC Championship game in Philly, when Brock Purdy got injured and Christian McCaffrey had to play quarterback.

I don't think the Eagles are going to do anything fancy. They're going to run the ball, get the play-action to throw outside to their receivers and then play great defence.

It's not cute, it's not exciting, but they just know how to win. I have a lot of faith in Jalen Hurts and their defence, so I'm going Eagles.

Los Angeles Chargers (7) @ New England Patriots (2) - 01:00 Mon

Playing at New England is tough in the cold and I think that makes a big difference. I don't know how much further the Patriots will go, but I think they'll win this.

Justin Herbert's been hit so many times. The Chargers' offensive line has just not been able to protect him. Like the Bills, their receivers haven't been able to get separation. It's like Herbert's the magic man again, whereas at least the Patriots have some receivers, and Drake Maye has been phenomenal.

I think he's earned the MVP because it's a great story. He's with a franchise that's not been itself since Tom Brady left and it's unbelievable what he's done in his second year.

You can only say their schedule has been easy so many times. You still have to beat the teams in front of you, and he's been decisive, he's stepping up in the pocket and the way he throws the ball is beautiful.

Why the NFL play-offs are the 'most unusual' in years

Houston Texans (5) @ Pittsburgh Steelers (4) - 01:00 Tue

The Steelers' win on Sunday was wild, but I think we have the same conversation around them every year. Mike Tomlin's done a great job, they've got a winning record again and got to the play-offs, but for so long it's not been more than that.

I'm going for the Texans because of their defence, it's just ferocious. Danielle Hunter has 15 sacks, Will Anderson is second in the NFL with a career-high 85 QB pressures, and they have four players with four interceptions. That's a crazy stat - which of their defensive backs do you throw towards?

Aaron Rodgers is doing tons trying to get the Steelers' offence on the same page but they're still having miscues. DK Metcalf is back from suspension but I just don't see them having enough firepower to compete with this defence.

It's the main reason the Texans could make it deep into the play-offs. They can cause a lot of trouble for a lot of people.

Phoebe Schecter was speaking to BBC Sport's Ben Collins.
